Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14, for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in a residential tenancy.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 and 19A.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 and 19A, because the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court Department.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and 6.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and 6, because the Premises are located in Worcester, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred in Worcester County.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: The tenancy is a residential tenancy for dwelling purposes under Massachusetts law and is governed by G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, as well as the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: The tenancy is a residential tenancy for dwelling purposes under Massachusetts law and is governed by G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, as well as the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The tenancy is a residential tenancy for dwelling purposes under Massachusetts law and is governed by G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, as well as the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.

105 C.M.R. 410.550 and 105 C.M.R. 410.60.proposition: The presence of mice and recurrent mouse droppings in a residential kitchen constitutes a condition that may endanger or materially impair the health, safety, or well-being of occupants, in violation of the State Sanitary Code, including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.550 and 105 C.M.R. 410.602.

105 C.M.R. 410.550(B).proposition: Under 105 C.M.R. 410.550(B), the owner of a dwelling containing two or more units is responsible for maintaining the premises free from rodent infestation and is required to exterminate rodents when necessary.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that serious and ongoing conditions that materially impair a tenant’s use and enjoyment of leased premises can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recognizes that substantial and ongoing interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment—here, loud late-night music and disturbances from a nearby lounge—constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and can amount to constructive eviction. In doing so, the court relies on and cites a line of earlier Massachusetts cases involving serious, persistent conditions (smoke, soot, loss of heat, obstruction of light and air, undermining of a building) as prior examples where such interferences breached quiet enjoyment. This directly aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts courts have long recognized such conditions as breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment... There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959)... Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381 (1942)... Case v. Minot, 158 Mass. 577, 587 (1893)... Skally v. Shute, 132 Mass. 367, 370-371 (1882).”}

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that serious and ongoing conditions that materially impair a tenant’s use and enjoyment of leased premises can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the common‑law covenant of quiet enjoyment, describing it as a long‑recognized tenant right against serious interferences that impair the character and value of leased premises. It relies on earlier Massachusetts cases (Winchester, Brande, Westland, Shindler, Blackett) to explain that modern liability does not require malicious intent, but arises where the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s acts or omissions is interruption of the tenant’s rights—i.e., material impairment of use and enjoyment. Thus, it affirms that serious ongoing conditions like the flooding here can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is also implicated when a landlord fails to remedy conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code and materially interfere with the tenant’s lawful use of the premises.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely links liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment to a landlord’s negligent failure to repair known defects, and expressly cites failure to repair code-related defects (including failure to “bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so”) as conduct that violates § 14. While the case’s immediate context is lead paint, the court reaffirms that a landlord’s failure to repair defects of which it has notice that materially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment (i.e., habitability and sanitary code-type violations) constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment. Thus it supports the proposition that quiet enjoyment is implicated by failure to remedy State Sanitary Code conditions materially interfering with lawful use.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “Twelve years later, in Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, supra, we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless in disregarding his tenant’s rights, and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14. Id. at 789. We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285–86 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is also implicated when a landlord fails to remedy conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code and materially interfere with the tenant’s lawful use of the premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment in terms of serious interference with tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions, specifically the landlord’s failure to take measures against third-party criminal activity. It does not tie quiet enjoyment to violations of the State Sanitary Code or articulate any rule that Sanitary Code violations that materially interfere with use of the premises, by themselves, implicate the covenant. That Sanitary Code-based standard appears only in the court’s discussion of the warranty of habitability, not in its analysis of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789–90 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord’s liability for quiet enjoyment does not require proof of malice or intent to harm; it is sufficient that the landlord knew or reasonably should have known of the conditions and failed to take reasonable steps to correct them, thereby causing substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The court squarely addresses the level of fault required under G.L. c. 186, § 14, rejecting the trial judge’s view that ‘reckless’ conduct is necessary and explaining that negligence suffices. It emphasizes that malicious intent is not required, that a landlord’s conduct rather than intent is controlling, and finds liability where the landlord had notice of serious code violations and failed adequately to correct them, causing substantial impairment of the premises’ value. This aligns with the proposition that knowledge (or reason to know) plus failure to take reasonable corrective steps, resulting in substantial interference, is enough.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “We concluded in the Solomon case, with respect to civil liability, that ‘malicious intent is not necessary, and that the statute covers, at the least, reckless conduct’… These statements are not incompatible with the imposition of liability based on negligence… A ‘landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling,’ Blackett v. Olanoff, supra at 716, on the question whether there has been a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations… [and] failure adequately to correct these violations… would impair substantially the value of the leased premises… On the facts… a violation of § 14 has been shown.”}

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–200 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: In addition, Massachusetts law recognizes an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, under which a landlord must maintain premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, and violations of the Code that significantly affect habitability can support or overlap with a quiet enjoyment claim.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This is a concurring/dissenting opinion, not the majority, but Quirico, J. explicitly accepts that the court is recognizing an implied obligation tied to State Sanitary Code standards and making rent obligations interdependent with compliance. He criticizes the majority’s broader, undefined “implied warranty of habitability” and instead would limit the warranty to compliance with the Code, acknowledging that violations materially affecting habitability can reduce rent and provide tenant remedies. That directly reflects Massachusetts recognition of an implied warranty linked to State Sanitary Code compliance, though the overlap with quiet enjoyment is not addressed here.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”}

McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 307–08 (1977)
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.proposition: In addition, Massachusetts law recognizes an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, under which a landlord must maintain premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, and violations of the Code that significantly affect habitability can support or overlap with a quiet enjoyment claim.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly treats this as a breach-of-implied-warranty-of-habitability case, rooted in Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, and repeatedly ties the warranty to compliance with the State Sanitary Code. It explains that Sanitary Code violations (major vs. minor, including in common areas) that affect the tenant’s use and enjoyment/“habitability” are compensable, and it notes the overlap with statutory enforcement mechanisms, thereby supporting the proposition that Code violations significantly affecting habitability can support or overlap with a quiet enjoyment–type claim. Although the word “quiet enjoyment” is not used, the described injury is the diminution of use and enjoyment of the premises tied to Code violations.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.relevant_excerpt:
“This case returns to us following its remand…for computation…of the damages owed to a tenant by his landlord for breach of the implied warranty of habitability. Under that warranty principle, first fully elaborated in this Commonwealth in Boston Housing Authy. v. Hemingway… the judge had awarded damages…for violations of the State Sanitary Code….
…[N]ot every defect gives rise to a diminution in rental value, and it has been held that isolated violations may be found not to constitute a breach of the warranty of habitability…. On the other hand, there may be instances in which minor violations in conjunction with major violations or a multitude of minor violations with a cumulative effect on habitability should be taken into consideration in reducing rent.”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 908–09 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: The presence of a rodent infestation in a dwelling unit, particularly in kitchen and food-preparation areas, is a condition that violates the State Sanitary Code and materially endangers or impairs the health and welfare of occupants.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion mentions the presence of mice and ants as among several State Sanitary Code violations in the apartment, but it does so only in a footnote listing various conditions and without any discussion of their legal significance, severity, or specific impact on health and welfare. The court neither analyzes rodent infestation separately nor holds that such infestation, particularly in kitchen or food-preparation areas, constitutes a State Sanitary Code violation that materially endangers occupants. Thus, the case does not establish or affirm the specific proposition stated.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: "The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks."

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761–62 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover either her actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent at the rate of $1,200.00 per month, whichever is greater, together with costs of the action and a reasonable attorney’s fee.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely construes G.L. c. 186, § 14 and explains that a lessor who interferes with quiet enjoyment is liable for “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.” The court further clarifies that when actual damages exceed three months’ rent, actual damages are the proper measure, but otherwise the tenant may recover three months’ rent, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. This matches the proposition’s statement of available remedies, even though the dollar amount there is case-specific and not from this opinion.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference ‘with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises’) shall ‘be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.’… Section 14 allows a minimum recovery of three months’ rent as an incentive to the pursuit of relief where the actual and consequential damages are slight or are difficult to prove. When the actual damages exceed three months’ rent, however, § 14 plainly states that actual damages should be the measure of recovery.”
